noun.description: A cylindrical device on which film, magnetic tape, thread, or other flexible materials can be wound; a reel.

verb.description: Wind (magnetic tape, thread, etc.) on to a spool.
examples: he was trying to spool his tapes back into the cassettes with a pencil eraser

verb.description: Send (data that is intended for printing or processing on a peripheral device) to an intermediate store.
examples: users can set which folder they wish to spool files to

verb.description: (of an engine) increase its speed of rotation, typically to that required for operation.
examples: a jet engine can take up to six seconds to spool up

origin: Middle English (denoting a spool for thread): shortening of Old French espole or from Middle Low German sp≈çle, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch spoel and German Spule. The verb dates from the early 17th century.
